segment.source: Packaging UWP apps
segment.target: Packaging UWP apps

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: To sell your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app or distribute it to other users, you need to create an appxupload package for it.
segment.target: To sell your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app or distribute it to other users, you need to create an appxupload package for it.

segment.source: When you create the appxupload, another appx package will be generated to use for testing and sideloading.
segment.target: When you create the appxupload, another appx package will be generated to use for testing and sideloading.

segment.source: You can distribute your app directly by sideloading the appx package to a device.
segment.target: You can distribute your app directly by sideloading the appx package to a device.

segment.source: This article describes the process of configuring, creating and testing a UWP app package.
segment.target: This article describes the process of configuring, creating and testing a UWP app package.

segment.source: For more information about sideloading, see Sideload Apps with DISM.
segment.target: For more information about sideloading, see Sideload Apps with DISM.

segment.source: For Windows 10, you generate one package (.appxupload) that can be uploaded to the Windows Store.
segment.target: For Windows 10, you generate one package (.appxupload) that can be uploaded to the Windows Store.

segment.source: Your app is then available to be installed and run on any Windows 10 device.
segment.target: Your app is then available to be installed and run on any Windows 10 device.

segment.source: Here are the steps to create an app package.
segment.target: Here are the steps to create an app package.

segment.source:
Before packaging your app
.
segment.target:
Before packaging your app
.

segment.source: Follow these steps to make sure your app is ready to be packaged for store submission.
segment.target: Follow these steps to make sure your app is ready to be packaged for store submission.

segment.source:
Configure an app package
.
segment.target:
Configure an app package
.

segment.source: Use the manifest designer to configure the package.
segment.target: Use the manifest designer to configure the package.

segment.source: For example, add tile images and choose the orientations your app supports.
segment.target: For example, add tile images and choose the orientations your app supports.

segment.source:
Create an app package
.
segment.target:
Create an app package
.

segment.source: Use the wizard in Microsoft Visual Studio to create an app package and then certify your package with the Windows App Certification Kit.
segment.target: Use the wizard in Microsoft Visual Studio to create an app package and then certify your package with the Windows App Certification Kit.

segment.source:
Sideload you app package
.
segment.target:
Sideload you app package
.

segment.source: After sideloading your app to a device, you can test that it works correctly.
segment.target: After sideloading your app to a device, you can test that it works correctly.

segment.source: After you have completed the steps above, you are ready to sell your app in the store.
segment.target: After you have completed the steps above, you are ready to sell your app in the store.

segment.source: If you have a line-of-business (LOB) app, that you don't plan to sell because it's for internal users only, you can sideload this app to install it on any Windows 10 device.
segment.target: If you have a line-of-business (LOB) app, that you don't plan to sell because it's for internal users only, you can sideload this app to install it on any Windows 10 device.

segment.source: Before packaging your app
segment.target: Before packaging your app

segment.source: Test your app.
segment.target: Test your app.

segment.source: Before you package your app for store submission, make sure it works as expected on all device families that you plan to support.
segment.target: Before you package your app for store submission, make sure it works as expected on all device families that you plan to support.

segment.source: These device families may include desktop, mobile, Surface Hub, XBOX, IoT devices, or others.
segment.target: These device families may include desktop, mobile, Surface Hub, XBOX, IoT devices, or others.

segment.source: Optimize your app.
segment.target: Optimize your app.

segment.source: You can useVisual Studio’s profiling and debugging tools to optimize the performance of your UWP app.
segment.target: You can useVisual Studio’s profiling and debugging tools to optimize the performance of your UWP app.

segment.source: For example, the Timeline tool for UI responsiveness, the memory Usage tool, the CPU Usage tool, and more.
segment.target: For example, the Timeline tool for UI responsiveness, the memory Usage tool, the CPU Usage tool, and more.

segment.source: For more information about these tools, see Run diagnostic tools without debugging.
segment.target: For more information about these tools, see Run diagnostic tools without debugging.

segment.source: Check .NET Native compatibility (for VB and C\# apps).
segment.target: Check .NET Native compatibility (for VB and C\# apps).

segment.source: With the UWP, there is now a new native compiler that will improve the runtime performance of your app.
segment.target: With the UWP, there is now a new native compiler that will improve the runtime performance of your app.

segment.source: With this change, it is highly recommended that you test your app in this compilation environment.
segment.target: With this change, it is highly recommended that you test your app in this compilation environment.

segment.source: By default, the Release build configuration enables the .NET native toolchain, so it is important to test your app with this Release configuration and check that your app behaves as expected.
segment.target: By default, the Release build configuration enables the .NET native toolchain, so it is important to test your app with this Release configuration and check that your app behaves as expected.

segment.source: Some common debugging issues that can happen with .NET Native are explained in more detail here.
segment.target: Some common debugging issues that can happen with .NET Native are explained in more detail here.

segment.source: Configure an app package
segment.target: Configure an app package

segment.source: The app manifest file (package.appxmanifest.xml) has the properties and settings that are required to create your app package.
segment.target: The app manifest file (package.appxmanifest.xml) has the properties and settings that are required to create your app package.

segment.source: For example, properties in the manifest file describe the image to use as the tile of your app and the orientations that your app supports when a user rotates the device.
segment.target: For example, properties in the manifest file describe the image to use as the tile of your app and the orientations that your app supports when a user rotates the device.

segment.source: Visual Studio has a manifest designer that makes it easy for you to update the manifest file without editing the raw XML of the file.
segment.target: Visual Studio has a manifest designer that makes it easy for you to update the manifest file without editing the raw XML of the file.

segment.source: Visual Studio can associate your package with the Store.
segment.target: Visual Studio can associate your package with the Store.

segment.source: When you do this, some of the fields in the Packaging tab of the manifest designer are automatically updated.
segment.target: When you do this, some of the fields in the Packaging tab of the manifest designer are automatically updated.

source.pc: Configure a package with the manifest designer

target.pc: Configure a package with the manifest designer

segment.source: In Solution Explorer, expand the project node of your UWP app.
segment.target: In Solution Explorer, expand the project node of your UWP app.

segment.source: Double-click the Package.appxmanifest file.
segment.target: Double-click the Package.appxmanifest file.

segment.source: If the manifest file is already open in the XML code view, Visual Studio prompts you to close the file.
segment.target: If the manifest file is already open in the XML code view, Visual Studio prompts you to close the file.

segment.source: Now you can decide how to configure your app.
segment.target: Now you can decide how to configure your app.

segment.source: Each tab contains information that you can configure about your app and links to more information if necessary.
segment.target: Each tab contains information that you can configure about your app and links to more information if necessary.

segment.source: Check that you have all the images that are required for a UWP app on the Visual Assets tab.
segment.target: Check that you have all the images that are required for a UWP app on the Visual Assets tab.

segment.source: From the Packaging tab, you can enter publishing data.
segment.target: From the Packaging tab, you can enter publishing data.

segment.source: This is where you can choose which certificate to use to sign your app.
segment.target: This is where you can choose which certificate to use to sign your app.

segment.source: All UWP apps must be signed with a certificate.
segment.target: All UWP apps must be signed with a certificate.

segment.source: In order to sideload an app package, you need to trust the package.
segment.target: In order to sideload an app package, you need to trust the package.

segment.source: The certificate must be installed on that device to trust the package.
segment.target: The certificate must be installed on that device to trust the package.

segment.source: For more information about sideloading, see Enable your device for development.
segment.target: For more information about sideloading, see Enable your device for development.

segment.source: Save your file after you have made the necessary edits for your app.
segment.target: Save your file after you have made the necessary edits for your app.

segment.source: Create an app package
segment.target: Create an app package

segment.source: To distribute an app through the Store you must create an appxupload package.
segment.target: To distribute an app through the Store you must create an appxupload package.

segment.source: You can do that by using the Create App Packages wizard.
segment.target: You can do that by using the Create App Packages wizard.

segment.source: Follow these steps to create a package suitable for store submission with Microsoft Visual Studio 2015.
segment.target: Follow these steps to create a package suitable for store submission with Microsoft Visual Studio 2015.

segment.source: In Solution Explorer, open the solution for your UWP app project.
segment.target: In Solution Explorer, open the solution for your UWP app project.

segment.source: Right-click the project and choose Store->Create App Packages.
segment.target: Right-click the project and choose Store->Create App Packages.

segment.source: If this option is disabled or does not appear at all, check that the project is a UWP project.
segment.target: If this option is disabled or does not appear at all, check that the project is a UWP project.

segment.source: The Create App Packages wizard appears.
segment.target: The Create App Packages wizard appears.

segment.source: Select Yes in the first dialog asking if you want to build packages to upload to the Windows Store, then click Next.
segment.target: Select Yes in the first dialog asking if you want to build packages to upload to the Windows Store, then click Next.

segment.source: If you choose No here, Visual Studio will not generate the required .appxupload package you need for store submission.
segment.target: If you choose No here, Visual Studio will not generate the required .appxupload package you need for store submission.

segment.source: If you only want to sideload your app to run it on internal devices, then you can select this option.
segment.target: If you only want to sideload your app to run it on internal devices, then you can select this option.

segment.source: For more information about sideloading, see Enable your device for development.
segment.target: For more information about sideloading, see Enable your device for development.

segment.source: Sign in with your developer account to the Windows Dev Center.
segment.target: Sign in with your developer account to the Windows Dev Center.

segment.source: (If you don't have a developer account yet, the wizard will help you create one.)
segment.target: (If you don't have a developer account yet, the wizard will help you create one.)

segment.source: Select the app name for your package, or reserve a new one if you have not already reserved one with the Windows Dev Center portal.
segment.target: Select the app name for your package, or reserve a new one if you have not already reserved one with the Windows Dev Center portal.

segment.source: Make sure you select all three architecture configurations (x86, x64, and ARM) in the Select and Configure Packages dialog.
segment.target: Make sure you select all three architecture configurations (x86, x64, and ARM) in the Select and Configure Packages dialog.

segment.source: That way your app can be deployed to the widest range of devices.
segment.target: That way your app can be deployed to the widest range of devices.

segment.source: In the Generate app bundle listbox, select Always.
segment.target: In the Generate app bundle listbox, select Always.

segment.source: This makes the store submission process much simpler because you will only have one file to upload (.appxupload).
segment.target: This makes the store submission process much simpler because you will only have one file to upload (.appxupload).

segment.source: The single bundle will contain all the necessary packages to deploy to devices with each processor architecture.
segment.target: The single bundle will contain all the necessary packages to deploy to devices with each processor architecture.

segment.source: It is a good idea to include full PDB symbol files for the best crash analytics experience from the Windows Dev Center.
segment.target: It is a good idea to include full PDB symbol files for the best crash analytics experience from the Windows Dev Center.

segment.source: You can learn more about debugging with symbols by visiting Debugging with Symbols.
segment.target: You can learn more about debugging with symbols by visiting Debugging with Symbols.

segment.source: Now you can configure the details to create your package.
segment.target: Now you can configure the details to create your package.

segment.source: When you're ready to publish your app, you'll upload the packages from the output location.
segment.target: When you're ready to publish your app, you'll upload the packages from the output location.

segment.source: Click Create to generate your appxupload package.
segment.target: Click Create to generate your appxupload package.

segment.source: Now you will see this dialog.
segment.target: Now you will see this dialog.

segment.source: Validate your app before you submit it to the Store for certification on a local or remote machine.
segment.target: Validate your app before you submit it to the Store for certification on a local or remote machine.

segment.source: (You can only validate release builds for your app package and not debug builds.)
segment.target: (You can only validate release builds for your app package and not debug builds.)

segment.source: To validate locally, leave the Local machine option selected and click Launch Windows App Certification Kit.
segment.target: To validate locally, leave the Local machine option selected and click Launch Windows App Certification Kit.

segment.source: For more information about testing your app with the Windows App Certification Kit, see Windows App Certification Kit.
segment.target: For more information about testing your app with the Windows App Certification Kit, see Windows App Certification Kit.

segment.source: The Windows App Certification Kit performs tests and shows you the results.
segment.target: The Windows App Certification Kit performs tests and shows you the results.

segment.source: See Windows App Certification Kit tests.
segment.target: See Windows App Certification Kit tests.

segment.source: If you have a remote Windows 10 that you want to use for testing, you will need to install the Windows App Certification Kit manually on that device.
segment.target: If you have a remote Windows 10 that you want to use for testing, you will need to install the Windows App Certification Kit manually on that device.

segment.source: The next section will walk you through these steps.
segment.target: The next section will walk you through these steps.

segment.source: After you've done that, then you can select Remote machine and click Launch Windows App Certification Kit to connect to the remote device and run the validation tests.
segment.target: After you've done that, then you can select Remote machine and click Launch Windows App Certification Kit to connect to the remote device and run the validation tests.

segment.source: After WACK has finished and your app has passed, you are ready to upload to the store.
segment.target: After WACK has finished and your app has passed, you are ready to upload to the store.

segment.source: Make sure you upload the correct file.
segment.target: Make sure you upload the correct file.

segment.source: It can be found in the root folder of your solution \\\[AppName\]\\AppPackages and it will end with the .appxupload file extension.
segment.target: It can be found in the root folder of your solution \\\[AppName\]\\AppPackages and it will end with the .appxupload file extension.

segment.source: The name will be of the form \[AppName\]\_\[AppVersion\]\_x86\_x64\_arm\_bundle.appxupload.
segment.target: The name will be of the form \[AppName\]\_\[AppVersion\]\_x86\_x64\_arm\_bundle.appxupload.

source.pc: Validate your app package on a remote Windows 10 device

target.pc: Validate your app package on a remote Windows 10 device

segment.source: Enable your Windows 10 device for development by following the Enable your device for development instructions.
segment.target: Enable your Windows 10 device for development by following the Enable your device for development instructions.

segment.source: Important You cannot validate your app package on a remote ARM device for Windows 10.
segment.target: Important You cannot validate your app package on a remote ARM device for Windows 10.

segment.source: Download and install the remote tools for Visual Studio.
segment.target: Download and install the remote tools for Visual Studio.

segment.source: These tools are used to run the Windows App Certification Kit remotely.
segment.target: These tools are used to run the Windows App Certification Kit remotely.

segment.source: You can get more information about these tools including where to download them by visiting Run Windows Store apps on a remote machine.
segment.target: You can get more information about these tools including where to download them by visiting Run Windows Store apps on a remote machine.

segment.source: Download the required Windows App Certification Kit and then install it on your remote Windows 10 device.
segment.target: Download the required Windows App Certification Kit and then install it on your remote Windows 10 device.

segment.source: On the Package Creation Completed page of the wizard, choose the Remote Machine option button, and then choose the ellipsis button next to the Test Connection button.
segment.target: On the Package Creation Completed page of the wizard, choose the Remote Machine option button, and then choose the ellipsis button next to the Test Connection button.

segment.source: Note The Remote Machine option button is available only if you selected at least one solution configuration that supports validation.
segment.target: Note The Remote Machine option button is available only if you selected at least one solution configuration that supports validation.

segment.source: For more information about testing your app with the WACK, see Windows App Certification Kit.
segment.target: For more information about testing your app with the WACK, see Windows App Certification Kit.

segment.source: Specify a device form inside your subnet, or provide the Domain Name Server (DNS) name or IP address of a device that's outside of your subnet.
segment.target: Specify a device form inside your subnet, or provide the Domain Name Server (DNS) name or IP address of a device that's outside of your subnet.

segment.source: In the Authentication Mode list, choose None if your device doesn't require you to log onto it by using your Windows credentials.
segment.target: In the Authentication Mode list, choose None if your device doesn't require you to log onto it by using your Windows credentials.

segment.source: Choose the Select button, and then choose the Launch Windows App Certification Kit button.
segment.target: Choose the Select button, and then choose the Launch Windows App Certification Kit button.

segment.source: If the remote tools are running on that device, Visual Studio connects to it and then performs the validation tests.
segment.target: If the remote tools are running on that device, Visual Studio connects to it and then performs the validation tests.

segment.source: See Windows App Certification Kit tests.
segment.target: See Windows App Certification Kit tests.

segment.source: Sideload your app package
segment.target: Sideload your app package

segment.source: With UWP app packages, you cannot simply install an app to your device like Desktop apps.
segment.target: With UWP app packages, you cannot simply install an app to your device like Desktop apps.

segment.source: Typically, you download these apps from the Store and that is how they are installed on your device.
segment.target: Typically, you download these apps from the Store and that is how they are installed on your device.

segment.source: But you can sideload apps to your device without submitting them to the Store.
segment.target: But you can sideload apps to your device without submitting them to the Store.

segment.source: This lets you install them and test them out using the app package (.appx) that you have created.
segment.target: This lets you install them and test them out using the app package (.appx) that you have created.

segment.source: If you have an app that you don’t want to sell in the Store, like a line-of-business (LOB) app, you can sideload that app so that other users in your company can use it.
segment.target: If you have an app that you don’t want to sell in the Store, like a line-of-business (LOB) app, you can sideload that app so that other users in your company can use it.

segment.source: The following list provides requirements for sideloading your app.
segment.target: The following list provides requirements for sideloading your app.

segment.source: You must enable your device for development.
segment.target: You must enable your device for development.

segment.source: To sideload your app on a Windows 10 Mobile device, you must use the WinAppDeployCmd.exe tool.
segment.target: To sideload your app on a Windows 10 Mobile device, you must use the WinAppDeployCmd.exe tool.

source.pc: Sideload an app to a desktop, laptop, or tablet

target.pc: Sideload an app to a desktop, laptop, or tablet

segment.source: Copy the folders for the version that you want to install to the target device.
segment.target: Copy the folders for the version that you want to install to the target device.

segment.source: If you've created an app bundle, then you will have a folder based on the version number and a \_test folder.
segment.target: If you've created an app bundle, then you will have a folder based on the version number and a \_test folder.

segment.source: For example these two folders (where the version to install is 1.0.2):
segment.target: For example these two folders (where the version to install is 1.0.2):

segment.source: C:\\Projects\\MyApp\\MyApp\\AppPackages\\MyApp\_1.0.2.0
segment.target: C:\\Projects\\MyApp\\MyApp\\AppPackages\\MyApp\_1.0.2.0

segment.source: C:\\Projects\\MyApp\\MyApp\\AppPackages\\MyApp\_1.0.2.0\_Test
segment.target: C:\\Projects\\MyApp\\MyApp\\AppPackages\\MyApp\_1.0.2.0\_Test

segment.source: If you don't have an app bundle, then you can just copy the folder for the correct architecture and the corresponding test folder.
segment.target: If you don't have an app bundle, then you can just copy the folder for the correct architecture and the corresponding test folder.

segment.source: For example these two folders.
segment.target: For example these two folders.

segment.source: C:\\Projects\\MyApp\\MyApp\\AppPackages\\MyApp\_1.0.2.0\_x64
segment.target: C:\\Projects\\MyApp\\MyApp\\AppPackages\\MyApp\_1.0.2.0\_x64

segment.source: C:\\Projects\\MyApp\\MyApp\\AppPackages\\MyApp\_1.0.2.0\_x64\_Test
segment.target: C:\\Projects\\MyApp\\MyApp\\AppPackages\\MyApp\_1.0.2.0\_x64\_Test

segment.source: On the target device, opent he test folder.
segment.target: On the target device, opent he test folder.

segment.source: For example, C:\\Projects\\MyApp\\MyApp\\AppPackages\\MyApp\_1.0.2.0\_Test
segment.target: For example, C:\\Projects\\MyApp\\MyApp\\AppPackages\\MyApp\_1.0.2.0\_Test

segment.source: Right-click on the Add-AppDevPackage.ps1 file, then choose Run with PowerShell and follow the prompts.
segment.target: Right-click on the Add-AppDevPackage.ps1 file, then choose Run with PowerShell and follow the prompts.

segment.source: When the app package has been installed, you will see this message in your PowerShell window: Your app was successfully installed.
segment.target: When the app package has been installed, you will see this message in your PowerShell window: Your app was successfully installed.

segment.source: Note To open the shortcut menu on a tablet, touch the screen where you want to right-click, hold until a complete circle appears, then lift your finger.
segment.target: Note To open the shortcut menu on a tablet, touch the screen where you want to right-click, hold until a complete circle appears, then lift your finger.

segment.source: The shortcut menu appears after you lift your finger.
segment.target: The shortcut menu appears after you lift your finger.

segment.source: Click the Start button and then type the name of your app to launch it.
segment.target: Click the Start button and then type the name of your app to launch it.
